thread.title: App takes the terror out of typography
thread.title_full: App takes the terror out of typography

author: Cynthia Karena
title: App takes the terror out of typography
text:
Salute the Desk prompts yoga in the office. Photo: Supplied
Typorama
By: Sarp Erdag, typorama.co
For: iPhone
Mapstr allows you to customise your maps. Photo: Supplied
Cost: free, with in-app purchases
Advertisement This is an easy and quick way to create stylish content for social media, flyers, or to add text to your own photos. Choose from a library of backgrounds or from your camera roll, then add text or use a cheesy random Quote: from the app. Text styles, filters, shadows, overlays and adjustments such as exposure, saturation and blurring are simple to use. The text styles are diverse and imaginative, and save you from having to think too much about design and layout. There's a useful watermark option to automatically brand all your creations, which can also be used to insert a logo.
Mapstr
Customise social media posts with Typorama. Photo: Supplied
By: Hulab, mapstr.com
For: iPhone
Cost: free
Tired of seeing cafes, shops or museums on maps that someone else decided are important? Personalise your own maps by populating them with your favourite places, with the useful option of adding notes. Save places to your map either by using your current location, entering a name or address, or scanning an address using your camera. Scanning an address from a magazine or newspaper works surprisingly well. Use standard tags to identify places, such as shopping or restaurants. There's also a handy option to create your own tags and place icons. Well chosen tags allow you to easily list, say, all cafes or parks. You can also find opening hours and phone numbers.
WORTH A LOOK
Salute the Desk (iPhone, $3.79) Stuck at your desk all day? This app gives a few ideas for yoga poses to help you stretch, relax, and importantly get rid of slouchy desk posture. There are no contortionist poses, instead a variety of stretches suited to being in a chair. Just remember to breathe. By Fiona Patterson; salutethedesk.com .
